abstract.text: Add particle effects to your app by creating repeatable particles.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Creating a SpriteKit particle emitter in Xcode

inlineContent.text: Use the SpriteKit particle emitter editor to experiment with SpriteKit
particle effects and see the results immediately. The visual interface separates
the task of designing particle effects from the programming, so artists can
create effects independent of your code.
The editor lets you modify many of the properties of a particle emitter, including:
Where the emitter creates particles
The number of particles the emitter creates
The rotation, size, and movement of particles
How each particle changes throughout its lifetime

content.text: Add a particle emitter resource file to your project

inlineContent.text: Choose File > New > File.
Choose Resource > SpriteKit Particle File, and click Next.
Select one of the preinstalled particle emitter textures, and click Next.
In the next sheet, choose a location and enter a filename.
Select the checkbox associated with your project and click Create. Xcode
creates a particle emitter file with the extension
Select the new particle emitter file in the Project navigator. Xcode opens
the file in the particle emitter editor.

content.text: Add a particle emitter to a scene

inlineContent.text: The SpriteKit particle emitter editor displays a preview of the emitter, but
doesnâ€™t add the emitter to your SpriteKit scene. Use code to add your particle
emitter to a scene, or use the SpriteKit scene editor to create a reference node
that points to your particle emitter file. When the scene is loaded, your particle
emitter is rendered as child of the reference node.
To add a reference node for your particle emitter to a SpriteKit scene:
In the Project navigator, select the scene file.
Click the Library button (+) in the toolbar, then drag a reference node from
the library to your scene.
Select the reference node and open the Attributes inspector.
Enter a name in the Name field.
In the Reference pop-up field, choose the particle emitter file.

content.text: Choose the shape of a particle

inlineContent.text: Choose the shape of your particle by selecting a texture. Each particle that the emitter creates
is based on a texture image that can be a solid shape or a
complex picture. You can use any image associated with the project as a
particle texture. The system applies all the particle emitterâ€™s modifications to the
selected image.
In the Texture pop-up field, choose a particle texture. Keep in mind that the
larger or more complex a particle image is, the more resources it uses. Use the
smallest and least complex image possible for the desired effect.
You can change the color of a particle throughout its lifetime and determine
how a particle blends in with other images.
Use the
Color Blend
fields to control how the particle blends its color
with its textureâ€™s inherent color.
In the Color Blend fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click
in the fields and enter the color blend values.
The average starting value of the blend factor. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The valid interval of values is from
up to and including
. A value above or below that interval is clamped to the minimum (
) if below or the maximum (
) if above. The default value is
, which means that the texture is used as is, ignoring the particleâ€™s color. Otherwise, the texture is blended with the color.
The range value creating a random variance of the starting color blend for each particle. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
The rate at which to modify the color blend for each particle, measured in change per second. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
Use the
Color Ramp
field to change the color of a particle throughout its
life cycle. You can have a particle go through as many color changes as you want
during a particleâ€™s life cycle. The particle changes colors based on the space
between color sliders.
In the Color Ramp field, click anywhere in the field to add a new color slider
to the color ramp. To create an immediate change of color, place two color sliders
on top of each other so thereâ€™s no space between them on the color ramp.
Use the
Blend Mode
field to determine how each particle blends with other
images in your app. This value corresponds to
enumeration. The
default value is
In the Blend Mode pop-up field, select one of the options.
Use the
Alpha
fields to modify the particleâ€™s transparency. The particleâ€™s
color is the result of multiplying the particleâ€™s alpha value with the texture
and color blending state. The particle color is then blended with the parentâ€™s
framebuffer before the particle is displayed.
In the Alpha fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click
in the fields and enter the alpha values.
The average starting transparency value applied to each particle. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value is
The range of allowed random values for the particleâ€™s starting alpha value. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value is
The rate at which the alpha value changes, measured in change per second. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
Use the
Background
field to change the background color shown in the Xcode
preview to help you visualize how the emitter will look in different environments.
In the Background pop-up menu, choose a color. If the color you want to use isnâ€™t
listed, choose Other to bring up the color picker. To create an emitter with no
background color, set the opacity in the color picker to
The color you pick for the background persists until you change it again. Xcode
saves the background color when you build the app, but doesnâ€™t use the color at
runtime.

content.text: Specify the movement and physics reactions

inlineContent.text: You can control different aspects of where a particle is created and the speed
and angle at which the particle moves after creation.
The
Position Range
fields define the area in which the emitter creates
particles. Particles are created within the rectangle centered on the position
defined in the scene and bounded by the position range values.
In the Position Range fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or
double-click in the fields and enter a value.
These values create the vector corresponding to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value is (
The value corresponding to the
property. The default value is
The
Angle
fields control the direction, in degrees, that particles move
away from the emitter. Entering
degrees moves the particles directly to the
right. The degrees work on a counterclockwise rotation, so entering
in the
Start field sends the particles to the top of the screen.
In the Angle fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click in
the fields and enter the angle values.
The average initial direction of a particle. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
The range of allowed random values for particleâ€™s direction at birth. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
Degrees versus radians â€” the particle emitter inspector displays degrees
when presenting an angle to the user. However, these degrees are converted into
radians to match the SpriteKit API when the app is built.
The
Speed
fields define how fast the particle is moving, in points per second,
at the instance of creation.
In the Speed fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) buttons, or double-click
in the fields and enter the speed values. The start and range values correspond
to the particle emitterâ€™s
and
properties.
The
Acceleration
fields modify the velocity of a particle after it is
created. You can use this to simulate an overall gravity effect, wind blowing
smoke from a fire, or other effects.
In the Acceleration fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or
double-click in the fields and enter the acceleration values.
Specifies acceleration along the horizontal axis. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
Specifies acceleration along the vertical axis. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
Use the
Field Mask
field to specify the categories of physics fields that
can exert forces on your particles. By default, particles are not affected by
physics fields. The value you provide corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
In the Field Mask field, double-click in the field and enter a field mask value,
or click the up or down arrow to change the value.

content.text: Adjust the size and rotation of particles

inlineContent.text: You can adjust a particleâ€™s size during its lifetime and control the speed and
direction in which the particle rotates when the emitter creates it.
The
Scale
fields manipulate the default size to determine the size of each
particle at birth and whether the particle expands or shrinks during its
lifetime. The default size of a particle is equal to the size of the particleâ€™s
texture, measured in points.
In the Scale fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click
in the fields and enter the values.
The average starting scale for each particle, corresponding to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value of
maintains the initial size of the particles. Values greater than
and less than
reduce the size of the particles, and values greater than
increase the size of the particles.
The range of allowed random values that modify the scale value. The range value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value of
has no effect on the scale value.
The rate at which the scale factor changes per second, corresponding to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value of
has no effect on the scale value.
The
Rotation
fields control the speed and direction that the particles rotate
when rendered in a scene. You can use these fields to simulate falling leaves,
spinning snowflakes, and any object that needs to rotate.
In the Rotation fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click
in the fields and enter the rotation values.
The average initial rotation of a particle, expressed as an angle in radians. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
The range of allowed random values, expressed as an angle in radians. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
A particleâ€™s rate of rotation, expressed in radians per second. This value corresponds to the
property.

content.text: Specify the life cycle for particles

inlineContent.text: You can manage how many particles are created, the maximum number of particles
created, and the length of time that each particle is alive.
The number of particles the emitter creates and how long they are onscreen
directly affect the performance of your app.
The
Emitter
fields control how often particles are created and the maximum
number of particles created.
In the Emitter fields, the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click in the
fields and enter a value.
The number of particles created per second. This value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property. The default value is
The maximum number of particles created. The default value is
, which indicates that the emitter creates an endless stream of particles. The maximum value corresponds to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
The
Lifetime
fields control how long, in seconds, each individual particle
is onscreen.
In the Lifetime fields, click the minus (â€”) or plus (+) button, or double-click
in the fields and enter a value.
The average starting value, corresponding to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s lifetime, corresponding to the particle emitterâ€™s
property.

abstract.text: Build, test, and submit your app with Appleâ€™s integrated development environment.
Add images, strings, data files, and other resources to your projects, and
manage how you load them at runtime.
The modes that describe how the source and destination pixel colors are used to calculate the new destination color.
The source and destination colors are blended by multiplying the source alpha value.
The average initial direction of a particle, expressed as an angle in radians.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s initial direction, expressed as an angle in radians.
A mask that defines which categories of physics fields can exert forces on the particles.
The number of particles the emitter should emit before stopping.
The average starting alpha value for a particle.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s starting alpha value.
The rate at which the alpha value of a particle changes per second.
The rate at which new particles are created.
The average starting value for the color blend factor.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s starting color blend factor.
The rate at which the color blend factor changes per second.
The average lifetime of a particle, in seconds.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s lifetime.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s position.
The average initial rotation of a particle, expressed as an angle in radians.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s initial rotation, expressed as an angle in radians.
The speed at which a particle rotates, expressed in radians per second.
The average initial scale factor of a particle.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s initial scale.
The rate at which a particleâ€™s scale factor changes per second.
The average initial speed of a new particle, in points per second.
The range of allowed random values for a particleâ€™s initial speed.
The average starting depth of a particle.
The acceleration to apply to a particleâ€™s horizontal velocity.
The acceleration to apply to a particleâ€™s vertical velocity.
